admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. Lessons drawn from the
            project focus on general, country, and institutional
            aspects, respectively as follows: 1) the project highlighted
            the existing preparedness within the biodiversity community
            - at both the institutional, and individual levels - to
            support the intellectual, and financial development of
            biodiversity collections in developing countries :
            mentorship programs do provide the international exposure,
            needed to link researchers, and administrators to the global
            research community, while, high standard, and adequate
            storage facilities can, and are being established for
            collection of major biodiversity importance; 2) similarly,
            at the country level, despite economic, and political
            adversity, the Government's commitment to co-finance,
            and develop modern standards in biodiversity collections was
            responsive to its Biodiversity Action Plan, extended to the
            regional biodiversity collections through internship
            programs; and, 3) prerequisites needed to undertake changes,
            should include management support at the institutional level
            regarding research, technical assistance, and flexible
            project design to incorporate the development of information
            technology as the backbone for collections management, and
            information dissemination.
